snippet: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin travels to Sevastapol, using the anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany to flout international condemnation and assert his country's right to annex Crimea; Putin, over past decade, has gradually turned Victory Day into a celebration of resurgent Russian power and nationalism.

byline.contributor: Andrew E. Kramer contributed reporting from Donetsk, Ukraine.

lead_paragraph: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.

headline.main: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
headline.print_headline: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
